docs.title: List of bakers
docs.description: In this section, we will present how to find lists of bakers. Then as a delegator, we will see how to choose a baker.

docs.title: How baking works?
docs.description: In this section, we will discuss how baking works. The different actors of the mechanism and the technological solutions will be presented.

docs.title: CLI to become a baker
docs.description: In this chapter, we will see the CLI command lines for registering as a delegate. Then we will see how to exercise your rights as a baker, endorser, and accuser.

docs.title: Delegating
docs.description: In this chapter, we will see how to delegate your coins. We'll use command lines or simple wallets' built-in options.

docs.title: Exam
docs.description: Question 1

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: In this module, we will see how baking works for the Tezos blockchain. More precisely, we will see the different actors involved, from creating new blocks to their validation. We will then see the associated reward system, and how to deploy your own baker. Finally, we will present a list of existing bakers and the criteria to evaluate them.

docs.title: Rewards
docs.description: To maintain the network, Tezos needs bakers and endorsers. They stake their tokens and use their CPU, memory space and internet connection to create blocks, manage transactions, vote, and secure the network. In exchange for the completion of these tasks, bakers are rewarded with tokens from the transaction fees or tokens created by the network. Since the Carthage update, the reward system has been updated to make the network more robust against non-cooperative baking strategies.

docs.title: Exam
docs.description: Question 1

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: Before we start digging into Tezos itself, let's review the basics of blockchain and cryptocurrencies. This module will present a brief history of the blockchain, its main components, consensus' mechanisms and introduce the notion of smart contract (smart contracts will be more detailed in the dedicated chapter of the "Tezos Basics" module). All these notions will later be helpful in the following modules to understand how Tezos works and how it builds upon Bitcoin and Ethereum to become part of a new generation of blockchains.

docs.title: Main properties of the first "blockchain"
docs.description: In this chapter, we will dig deeper into the main properties of the Bitcoin protocol, its developers, its P2P network, and a few basics of its economic structure.

docs.title: Introduction to other consensus algorithms
docs.description: In this chapter, we will briefly introduce some other public consensus mechanisms.

docs.title: Proof-of-work
docs.description: Proof-of-work was the first fully functional blockchain consensus mechanism ever created. It is still in use by Bitcoin and many other blockchains. It requires its users to mine to get a chance to earn a reward for validating blocks of transactions. In this chapter, we will look into the technical side of things and how mining works.

docs.title: Smart Contracts
docs.description: In this chapter, we're going to explain how and why Bitcoin's programming features are limited. We'll define what Smart Contracts are and how they are already present on Bitcoin. And finally, we'll define what Gas is and why it was introduced on Ethereum.

docs.title: Become a baker or a delegator
docs.description: Becoming a baker or a delegate on Tezos is a great way to contribute to the ecosystem while earning some profits. Baking (also called staking) is the process of forming new blocks on Tezos. This process is part of the Proof-of-Stake consensus (more on that in the Tezos basics module). The more bakers, the more decentralized and statistically safe this process is.

frontMatter.title: Become a baker or a delegator

docs.description: Question 1

previous.title: Become a baker or a delegator

docs.title: Receive a grant
docs.description: The Tezos Foundation goal is to develop the Tezos ecosystem, which includes offering grant programs. In this chapter, we'll take a closer look at how it works.

previous.title: Contribute to the Tezos Core Protocol

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: Tezos is a user-centric blockchain. As seen in the governance chapter, its stakeholders' evolution of Tezos is decided. Anyone can contribute, from reporting a simple issue to coding and developing a whole new platform based on Tezos; many opportunities will benefit you and the ecosystem. In this module, we will see how to:

docs.title: Contribute to OpenTezos
docs.description: The excellent website you are currently browsing is called OpenTezos and will later be merged with the upcoming wiki.tezos.com. It is, therefore, important that all the content here is up-to-date and error-free. If you see an error, you can either submit an issue or go a step further by actually correcting the mistake yourself and submitting it for review. Here is how to proceed:

next.title: Contribute to the Tezos Core Protocol

docs.title: Report an issue
docs.description: The simplest way to contribute is to report issues you may encounter while using Tezos or its related platforms.

docs.title: Contribute to the Tezos Core Protocol
docs.description: The full source code of Tezos is available on gitlab.com/tezos. Tezos is written in OCaml, an industrial-strength programming language supporting functional, imperative and object-oriented styles [1]. OCaml is a functional programming language that offers speed, unambiguous syntax and semantics, and formal proofs of correctness.

frontMatter.title: Contribute to the Tezos Core Protocol

docs.title: Build a dapp - User Experience
docs.description: In the previous chapter, the basic usages of the Temple Wallet were covered. The React app that was developed is functional.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: One of the main features of blockchains is the decentralization: each transaction sent is verified by multiple nodes and its validation process does not rely on a single trusted third party.

docs.title: Taquito
docs.description: Interactions with a Tezos blockchain can be done thanks to the Tezos CLI.

docs.title: Temple Wallet
docs.description: Dapp users need to have both addresses and the associated private keys of these addresses. They want to be able to securely store their private keys, easily use and manage their addresses, and easily use the different dapps. All of this can be performed by some tools called wallets. They can be desktop applications, browser plugins, hardware or smart contracts...

docs.title: Smart contract deployment with Truffle
docs.description: The first step to creating a Dapp is to deploy a smart contract onto a Tezos network, whether for testing or real-life use. There are several ways to do this, like using the Tezos CLI.

docs.title: Cross-chain Swaps
docs.description: Swap scenarios

docs.title: Decentralized Exchanges
docs.description: An exchange is a marketplace where coins and tokens are traded. The core function of an exchange is to ensure fair, orderly trading and the efficient dissemination of price information for everyone trading on the exchange. Exchanges give companies, traders, and crypto-enthusiasts a platform from which to sell and buy crypto-currencies publicly.

docs.title: Exam
docs.description: Question 1

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: What is DeFi?

docs.title: Lending and Flash Loans
docs.description: In your life, you have probably had to borrow money, e.g., for a student loan, a car loan, or a mortgage. Lending and borrowing are essential services in any financial system. Traditionally, lenders such as banks, provide you with a loan in exchange for a fee in the form of an interest rate. Repaying the said loan is enforced by legal contracts with the bank.

docs.title: On-chain Oracles
docs.description: Definition

docs.title: Stablecoins
docs.description: A stablecoin is a cryptocurrency whose price is fixed to another asset. Most stablecoins are pegged (fixed) to fiat currencies (currencies issued by the central bank of a sovereign state) like the US Dollar.

docs.title: Synthetics
docs.description: Synthetics are contracts where two parties bet on opposite outcomes for the value of an asset and then split the difference in profit/loss. The actual asset is not purchased in this contract. Both parties simply bet on the value appreciating or depreciating.

docs.title: Token Standards
docs.description: In the Blockchain ecosystem, any digitally transferable asset between two people is called a token. Tokens can be native to a blockchain, e.g., BTC is the native token of Bitcoin or tokens can also be created and hosted on an existing blockchain via a smart contract. Some tokens, called stablecoins, follow the price of fiat currencies (e.g., USD, EUR). Others, called NFT, can represent collectables or art pieces. Finally, tokens can represent rights of ownership of real-world estates or companies (i.e., stock tokens). In this chapter, we will see the main types of token and the token standards on Tezos.

docs.title: Wrapped Assets
docs.description: Wrapped XTZ

docs.description: In this chapter, we will see how Tezos is multi-network. We will learn what the "main network" and the "test networks" are and finally, we will discover how to configure our node on a chosen network.

docs.title: Set-up a node
docs.description: In this chapter, we will see how to create and deploy your own node.

docs.description: To better understand formal verification, let's first describe the theory and tools behind the formal analysis.

docs.title: Generalities
docs.description: Formal verification is a complex task but made possible and easier on Tezos smart contracts with proof assistant tools (such as Coq) and Michelson conception choices.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: The Tezos blockchain has several advantages over its concurrents. One of them is the formal verification of smart contract. This module shows a brief overview of how Tezos smart contracts can be formally verified.

docs.title: Mi-Cho-Coq
docs.description: Introduction

docs.title: Formal verification on smart contracts
docs.description: This section describes how to bridge the Tezos world (and the Michelson language) with the formal world of Coq. For this, we are going to model a theorem representing a smart contract and its purpose (i.e. the goal of the smart contract).

docs.title: Smart Contract
docs.description: A Tezos smart contract is a piece of code written in the Michelson language (a low-level stack-based Turing-complete language).

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: Tezos smart contracts are written in Michelson, which is a stack-based language and the lowest level of language for a Tezos smart contract. The Michelson code can be deployed as-is on the Tezos network.

docs.title: Smart contract development in PascaLIGO
docs.description: The language used in smart contracts on Tezos is Michelson, a stack-based language. However, this kind of language is not commonly used by developersa and as the code becomes complex and longer, it grows increasingly harder to keep readable and clean code in Michelson. However, the Tezos ecosystem provides some high-level languages alternatives, which make smart contracts development as easy as any application development.

docs.title: Instructions Reference
docs.description: This chapter provides an explicit list of all the most commonly used instructions in Michelson. It intends to describe common Michelson instructions with a graphical illustration.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: To write smart contracts for Tezos, one can either choose the official low-level language called Michelson, or a high-level language, such as LIGO or SmartPy, which compiles into Michelson.

docs.description: This section introduces the main concepts of the Michelson language. It begins with the basics of stack manipulation then focuses on primitive types and more complex data structures. Finally the chapter focuses on specific features related to smart contracts concepts.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: This module aims to teach developers to write smart contracts with SmartPy. It will take the form of a course, illustrated through an example of a smart contract, to help the developer acquire the essentials to write, test, and analyze his smart contract.

docs.title: Smart contract development with SmartPy
docs.description: In this chapter, we will use SmartPy to develop a smart contract based Raffle and cover the most important aspects of the framework. We will use this opportunity to introduce new notions as they appear. For a complete reference of SmartPy, please refer to the Reference Manual.

docs.title: CLI and RPC
docs.description: In this chapter, the reader will learn how to install the official "tezos-client" and "tezos-admin-client" applications and run them using the Command Line Interface. These commands call on the remote procedures of a Tezos node (local or remote). There are many commands, but we'll see some examples.

frontMatter.title: CLI and RPC
frontMatter.authors: Thomas Zoughebi, Aymeric Bethencourt, and Maxime Fernandez

docs.title: Economics and rewards
docs.description: In this chapter, we will dig deeper into the fees of the Tezos network and the baking and endorsing rewards. The calculations you'll learn about are helpful from the simplest transaction issuance to the most complex application built on Tezos. That is why it is important to understand the basics of fees and gas optimizations. Of course, this will be particularly useful if you are a baker or an endorser.

docs.title: Governance on-chain
docs.description: Tezos is a self-amending blockchain network that incorporates an on-chain mechanism for proposing, selecting, testing, and activating protocol upgrades without needing to use hard forks [1].

frontMatter.title: Governance on-chain
frontMatter.authors: Thomas Zoughebi, Aymeric Bethencourt, and Maxime Fernandez

docs.title: History of amendments
docs.description: As presented in the Governance on-chain chapter, the Tezos blockchain is constantly evolving, through new amendments. In this chapter, we will present an overview of past proposals and the reasons for their approval or disapproval.

frontMatter.title: History of amendments
frontMatter.authors: Thomas Zoughebi, Aymeric Bethencourt, and Maxime Fernandez

docs.title: Introduction
docs.description: Tezos is a public, open-source blockchain protocol relying on a low power consumption and energy-efficient consensus.

frontMatter.authors: Thomas Zoughebi, Aymeric Bethencourt, and Maxime Fernandez

docs.title: Liquid Proof-of-Stake
docs.description: In "Blockchain Basics" module, you understood that the main objective of a consensus mechanism is maintaining a common history throughout the whole peer-to-peer network. There are countless consensus algorithms, and they all have their pros and cons. Notably, Bitcoin's Proof-of-Work has two major flaws:

frontMatter.title: Liquid Proof-of-Stake
frontMatter.authors: Thomas Zoughebi, Aymeric Bethencourt, and Maxime Fernandez

docs.title: Operations
docs.description: This chapter introduces the notion of Operations on Tezos. These are more commonly known as Transactions on other blockchains and in Tezos are a subset of operations. On Tezos, transactions are transfers of tokens and smart contracts calls. A few examples of operations that are not transactions on Tezos: Originations; endorsements; proposals; ballots...

frontMatter.title: Operations
frontMatter.authors: Thomas Zoughebi, Aymeric Bethencourt, and Maxime Fernandez

docs.description: In this chapter, you will learn the basics of Tezos smart contracts. Their components and the workflow to deploy and use them on the Tezos blockchain.

docs.title: Voting
docs.description: In this chapter, we will have a brief overview of the voting process. We will also see different commands that allow a delegate to make a proposal and vote.

docs.title: Welcome to OpenTezos
docs.description: Welcome Tezos Developers! Explore the technical and economic concepts behind the Tezos Network, experiment with our tutorials, or start building your own Tezos Dapp. Each module will teach you a full concept of Tezos, ending with a quiz that will get you an official completion certification if you succeed.

docs.title: Paths
docs.description: Choose your own path
